meaning: Any cell that contains a nucleus storing genetic information. Found in plants and animals, and much larger than prokaryotic cells. Usually between 10 and 100 µm in diameter
A small type of cell without a nucleus - genetic material is a DNA loop, which may have one or two rings of DNA known as plasmids. Usually between 0.1 and 5.0 µm in diameter
An organelle found in eukaryotic cells that contains genetic material.
A fluid-like substance found in cells
The partially permeable membrane that controls what enters and leaves a cell
An organelle where respiration occurs
An organelle responsible for protein synthesis
An organelle found in plant cells that is responsible for photosynthesis
An organelle found in plant cells that stores cell sap
The outer layer of plant and algal cells responsible for strengthening the cell. Made of cellulose
A cell that has adapted to carry out a particular function
A sub-cellular structure specialised to carry out a particular function
The process where an unspecialised stem cell gains individual characteristics and functions
A type of DNA structure found in the nucleus of a cell. Usually found in pairs
A section of a chromosome containing the code for the production of a particular protein
An undifferentiated cell capable of creating specialised cells of the same type.
A type of stem cell found in embryos which is capable of differentiating into almost all kinds of cell found in the human body
A type of stem cell found in adults which is capable of differentiating into many kinds of cell found in the human body
A region of unspecialised cells in a plant capable of mitosis at any point throughout the plant's life
The process of cell divison where a single cell produces two genetically identical 'daughter' cells
A process where an embryo is produced which has the same genes as a patient. Its stem cells will not be rejected by the body
The series of stages which a cell goes through as it grows and divides
The process by which particles of a substance in solution, or of a gas, spread out in a way which results in a net movement from high concentration to low concentration
The process by which water molecules diffuse through a partially permeable membrane from a dilute solution to a concentrated one
The process by which substances move through a partially permeable membrane against the concentration gradient, using energy from respiration
